repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Education Sector Development
            Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education Sector
            Development Support Credit Project for Bangladesh were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the Bank performance
            was satisfactory, the Borrower performance was satisfactory,
            sustainability was likely, and institutional development
            impact was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: it
            is recommended that the grant-based financing scheme be
            piloted in new schools to test its attractiveness and
            merits, its potential impact on school performance as well
            as to appreciate the degree of buy-in by teachers and School
            Management Committees (SMCs). Ministry of Education (MOE) is
            shifting to grants-based financing system, where resources
            going to institutions will be linked more closely to
            students on a per capita basis, rather than to teachers as
            it is currently the case. A draft grants-based financing
            system has been finalized but not yet adopted and a decision
            was taken to suspend Monthly Pay Order (MPO) for new non
            government schools. As a result, newly registered schools
            are likely to experience financial constraints which may
            have adverse effect on their performance. There is a need to
            improve the capacity of Bangladesh Bureau of Education
            Information and Statistics (BANBEIS) to provide regular
            updates on schools and better monitor education outcomes
            since the last school census was conducted in 1999 and an
            update was undertaken in 2005. BANBEIS is expecting to start
            by June 2008 the next census as it is already approved and
            the process of releasing the funds has begun. There may also
            be a need to develop a platform for integrating multiple
            databases that fall under MOE as was already evidenced by
            the uniformization of school codes between Education Boards
            and BANBEIS. This integration process, across various units
            of MOE, would, for instance, help to institutionalize
            student learning assessment as Secondary Education Quality
            and Access Enhancement Project (SEQAEP) project intends to
            do by benchmarking learning levels in Bangladesh to
            international standards such as Trends in International
            Mathematics and Science Study (TIMSS) or Program for
            International Student Assessment (PISA).

repnme.cdata!:
Better governance improves quality of
            education in Bangladesh

abstracts.cdata!:
While Bangladesh has made impressive
            gains in access to education, governance constraints have
            contributed to the poor quality of education at all levels.
            The World Bank has supported the implementation of
            substantive policy reforms through a series of development
            support credits - education sector development support
            credit (ESDSC) I and II. There has been an appreciable
            improvement in quality of the secondary education system,
            with 80,000 more children passing grade 12 (as the pass
            rates increased from 40 percent in 2001 to 48 percent in
            2004), and improved governance and transparency in the
            system, including a fall in teacher absenteeism. The Bank is
            assisting the government in undertaking the third phase of
            the reform agenda aimed at addressing systemic governance
            issues in order to raise the quality and cost-effectiveness
            of service delivery, and improve equity of access to
            secondary education.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Programmatic Education Sector
            Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and likewise, satisfactory
            institutional development impacts. This Simplified
            Implementation Completion Report provides the findings and
            implications for subsequent operations, indicating this
            Programmatic Education Sector Adjustment Credit, as the
            first in a series of proposed policy reform credits in the
            education sector, has strong links to the overall
            Development Support Credits of the Bank, and to the Poverty
            Reduction Growth Facility supported by the International
            Monetary Fund (IMF). Notwithstanding, it is however
            realistic to assume that future reform initiatives might
            face resistance: the primary focus of this project was to
            establish institutional arrangements, and policy measures to
            ease governance problems - the focus of future proposed
            operations will be to deepen those reforms. Key among
            reforms will be the establishment of the autonomous NTRCA,
            and increased emphasis on teacher training, continuation of
            the process of privatization of textbook production at the
            secondary level, and potential extension of this process to
            the primary level, continued emphasis on linking financing
            of institutions to performance, and ensuring a significant
            role of communities in school management. For these reforms
            to succeed, it is critical that there is continued political
            commitment of the Government to reforms, of its ownership of
            the results, and of public receptivity of the reform
            initiatives. It is important to note that the first
            programmatic credit was discussed, negotiated and
            implemented at a time when the Government, overcoming its
            initial reservations, increasingly fortified its position to
            carry forward the reform actions. The timing was also
            appropriate, reasonably soon after the elections.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Programmatic Education Sector
            Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Programmatic Education Sector
            Adjustment Credit Project, will assist the Ministry of
            Education (MOE) in undertaking the first phase of a
            medium-term reform agenda, aimed at addressing systemic
            governance issues in order to raise the quality, and
            cost-effectiveness of service delivery, and improve equity
            of access in secondary education. The focus will be on
            reforms, to include a rigorous, and enforced criteria, that
            governs the establishment of institutions, and of
            institutional mechanisms that link school subsidies, to
            objective measures of school performance. Also strengthened,
            will be the school management committees, to allow them a
            greater role in school management. To enhance access to
            secondary schooling, MOE has been proves subsidies to girls
            at the secondary level, and, over the next few years,
            means-testing mechanisms will be piloted to better target
            these subsidies to the poor. Incentives will be provided to
            the private sector to set up institutions in underserved
            areas. Moreover, significant emphasis will be placed on
            program evaluation and monitoring to guide policymaking,
            namely information on standardized examination outcomes,
            school performance, and on program effectiveness. An
            autonomous Teacher registration and certification agency
            will be established, responsible for developing a roster of
            pre-qualified, and certified teachers. An apex institution
            will also be established to manage teacher training, and
            regulate training institutions, and, set standards for new,
            and in-service teachers. Finally, an enhanced transparency
            in textbook production and relevant, demand-driven
            curriculum will focus on privatizing textbook production,
            through the National Curriculum and Textbook Board (NCTB).
